intro: Physalis suberifera var. crassifolia, commonly known as the thick-leaved ground cherry, is a variant of the ground cherry species native to Central and South America. It is characterized by its thick, fleshy leaves and produces small, orange or red berries enclosed in a papery calyx. The plant typically grows in warm, humid climates and thrives in well-drained soil. Its foliage is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory properties. The fruit is edible when fully ripe and is sometimes used in culinary applications.
